overview_of_class: This course will consist in an intensive analysis of Moses Maimonides' views on God, the interpretation of sacred texts, creation, prophecy, providence, religious ritual, and human perfection. Reference will also be made to Aristotle, Plotinus, Alfarabi, Aquinas, Spinoza, and Kant.
name: Studies in Medieval Philosophy
title: WCAS PHIL 311-0-20 Studies in Medieval Philosophy
enrl_requirement: Enrollment Requirements: Students must have taken PHIL 210-1 or RELIGION 220-0 in order to register for this course.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course will consist in an intensive analysis of Moses Maimonides' views on God, the interpretation of sacred texts, creation, prophecy, providence, religious ritual, and human perfection. Reference will also be made to Aristotle, Plotinus, Alfarabi, Aquinas, Spinoza, and Kant.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Prerequisites: PHIL 210-1 or RELIGION 220 Or Consent of Instructor

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: The student will be expected to know the problems Maimonides' tried to solve, the general direction of his solutions, as well as the difficulties he encountered. As in all philosophy courses, this one will stress critical thinking.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: A medium length paper (1,500 words) and a long paper (3000-3500 words).

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
Moses Maimonides, GUIDE OF THE PERPLEXED, Vol. 1-2, trans. Shlomo Pines. University of Chicago Press
0-226-50230-9 (paperback) & 0-226-50231-7 (paperback)

Kenneth Seeskin, THE CAMBRIDGE COMPANION TO MAIMONIDES. Cambridge University Press. 0-521-52578-0 (paperback)
